Situation1: Got a request to attend court to provide testimony when required.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story: I woke up early, my uniform pressed and ready, knowing I was scheduled to testify in court today. As a police officer, I’m expected to act with integrity and fairness, and my testimony could be crucial for the case. The courthouse was across town, and I needed to be there on time. But as I stepped into the hallway, I saw the notice: a severe heat advisory had been issued. I remembered Mrs. Lee, my elderly neighbor who lived alone on our floor. As a citizen, I felt responsible for her well-being, especially on days like this. I knew she struggled with the heat and had no family nearby. I glanced at my watch, feeling the pressure of my duty to the court and my duty to my community. Should I check on Mrs. Lee and risk being late, or head straight to court and hope she’d be alright? The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
